title: What Do Video Games Mean To Us? - Kinda Funny Gamescast Ep. 92 (Pt. 4)
description:
What do video games mean to us?

Thanks to MVMT Watches for sponsoring this episode. Go to http://www.MVMTwatches.com/kinda

Subscribe! http://www.youtube.com/kindafunnygames?sub_confirmation=1

Subscribe! http://www.youtube.com/kindafunnygames?sub_confirmation=1

Support us and get the shows early here! http://www.patreon.com/kindafunnygames

Check out our store! http://www.kindafunny.com/store

Follow us on Twitter!
Tim - http://www.twitter.com/TimGettys
Greg - http://www.twitter.com/GameOverGreggy
Colin - http://www.twitter.com/NoTaxation
Kinda Funny - http://www.twitter.com/KindaFunnyVids

Every day Greg Miller, Colin Moriarty, and Tim Gettys talk about the biggest stories in Video Games.

Background Wall Art by Orioto - https://www.facebook.com/OriotoPosters/

What do video games mean to us? It's really inspiring, kind of. Just reading this reminded me something I already knew, but it reminded me how important games are to me and how important game culture is to me. It's not even so much about playing them, but about living them and thinking back on all the memories of my life. In no small way, I am who I am because of video games - my career, my job, all that. Obviously. But when I stop and think back on my life, and I think back about the friendships that I made and the relationships that I have, so many of them are birthed in video games in some way. Whether it's the hours of Co-op we played together or just waiting in line for the new Halo game to come out in front of a store, or just talking to your friends about what Mario 5 could look like - you know what I mean? It's just like it's a form of creative expression that goes so far beyond just experiencing it.

friends about what could Mario 5 look like, you know what I mean? Like just making things up in your head - it's just like it's a form of creative expression that goes so far beyond just experiencing it and interacting with it as it's happening. But it's it's it is kind of all-encompassing and it is a lifestyle, you know. And in the same way I think movies are too, and TV has been forever. But yeah, I mean, uh, picking up on your point - like this is the wave of the future, and it's not so much even the future anymore; it's the now. This is happening; this is how things are. And I think that it won't be long till video games are just something people just do.
